BIOS209
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
Cell signalling underlies the ability of cells to sense their environment and respond. In multicellular organisms, individual cells receive and integrate vast amounts of information that they use to modify their behaviour to ensure development and survival of the organism as a whole. Disruption in these lines of communication underlies almost all disease.

Despite the apparent complexity, diverse signalling processes are carried out by very similar sets of molecular components that interact in common patterns. This module will be taught by focussing on the common molecular themes and concepts that underlie normal cell signalling. This will be interspersed with disease case studies that show how disruption of these processes affects cells, tissues, and the whole organism. The module will be taught via live on-campus sessions. There will be synchronous sessions that also cover questions and answers and discussion points raised in the week’s material – focussing on ‘how do we know this’ to introduce students to research methodologies and data interrogation. Interactive discussion will be encouraged through enquiry-based learning (EBL) exercises, activities delivered through platforms such as Polls Everywhere, discussion boards and live on-campus workshops.

Assessment will follow the two cycle assessment strategy, comprising an open-book on-line assessment and an in person, unseen exam, that will focus on the evaluation of case studies, data analysis/interpretation.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

• Provide knowledge and understanding of the molecular mechanisms that allow cells to communicate with each other;
• Explain the common molecular themes and concepts that underlie normal cell signalling, illustrating these with specific examples;
• Illustrate how defects in these signalling processes can result in a variety of diseases;
• Outline the techniques that are used to investigate and define these pathways and to describe how these techniques are used in drug discovery programmes of research;
Marketing Module Synopsis
Cell signalling underlies the ability of cells to sense their environment and respond. In multicellular organisms, individual cells receive and integrate vast amounts of information that they use to modify their behaviour to ensure the development and survival of the organism as a whole. Disruption in these lines of communication underlies almost all disease.

Despite the apparent complexity, diverse signalling processes are carried out by very similar sets of molecular components that interact in common patterns. This module will be taught via lectures which focus on the common molecular themes and concepts that underlie normal cell signalling. This will be interspersed with disease case studies that show how disruption of these processes affect cells, tissues, and the whole organism.

Assessment will include an open-book on-line assessment and an in person, unseen exam, which will focus on the evaluation of case studies, data analysis/interpretation.
Outline Syllabus
Part 1: Introduction to Cell Signalling will be a general overview of the key principles of cell signalling and highlight the world-leading research being carried out at Liverpool

Part 2: 'Getting the message – Information transfer across membranes' will look at the ways cells have evolved to sense environmental signals at their membrane. This will include a discussion of transmembrane receptors linked to enzymatic activity, transmembrane receptors linked to G proteins, the ion channel family, and membrane-permeant signals (nitric oxide, oxygen, steroid hormones). It will also include case studies to highlight how disruption in these processes underlies human disease.

Part 3: 'Information processing inside the cell' will show how cells deal with the environmental information once it gets inside the cell. This will include a discussion of the different molecular 'currencies' that cells use to transfer/process information and make decisions (protein-protein interactions, conformational change, post-translational modifications, subcellular localisation, small signalling mediators etc). It will also include disease case studies.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching on this module will be delivered by live on-campus sessions (30 hours of lectures and 2 hours of workshops). The synchronous sessions will also cover questions and answers and discussion points raised in the week’s material – focus will particularly be on ‘how do we know this’ to introduce students to research methodologies and data interrogation. Interactive discussion will be encouraged through enquiry-based learning (EBL) exercises, activities delivered through platforms such as Polls Everywhere and discussion boards.

Self-directed learning: Guided and self-directed reading, reflection on learning, formative assessment (quizzes, discussion questions for synchronous sessions) and preparation for summative assessments.

Inclusivity: Students will have access to materials online such as teaching materials and online discussion boards. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Research-connected teaching: Students will have the opportunity to discuss contemporary research to apply new perspectives to their learning.

Active and peer-learning: Students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant top issues and share with each other their values and perspectives on preparing for their assignments. Similarly, there is an expectation that students will prepare and actively research topics for dissemination and discussion with each other both in the classroom environment and on the virtual learning environment (CANVAS). Workshops will be incorporated into the module that will allow students to work through case studies and data analysis problems. The format of these workshops will facilitate group work, active and peer learning and will also provide students with formative feedback to reinforce their understanding.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions and learning tasks. Students will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of academic writing, persuasive debate and applying research and theory to practice.

Digital Fluency: All materials will be made available on CANVAS.

Global Citizenship: Students will share their own perspectives on practice issues and reflect on local, national and global strategies and policy. They will discuss and analyse these in relation to healthcare practice both domestically and internationally.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment for this module will involve both open-book (Cycle 1; worth 40% of the the overall module mark) and unseen exam assessments (Cycle 2; worth 60%) which focus on the evaluation of case studies, data analysis/interpretation and experimental design.

Students will be prepared for the assessment through enquiry-based learning (EBL) exercises, activities delivered through platforms such as Polls Everywhere and discussion boards. In addition, on-line quizzes will be used to help students track their progress and workshops where students work through case study questions, data analysis and experimental design exercises will facilitate peer learning and provide formative feedback.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Deliveries

 LocationPeriod

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Analyse and evaluate the fundamental features of a range of important cell signalling mechanisms.
 LO2 Evaluate the nature and role of the different molecular components of intracellular signalling pathways.
 LO3 Explain how cell signalling processes may be defective, or modified, in a variety of different diseases.
 LO4 Analyse experimental data relating to the study of cell signalling.
 LO5 Critically evaluate the way modern therapeutics target defective signalling pathways to treat disease.
Skills

Skills

 S2 Critical thinking
 S3 Problem solving
 S4 Biological interpretation

The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment for this module will involve both open-book (Cycle 1; worth 40% of the the overall module mark) and unseen exam assessments (Cycle 2; worth 60%) which focus on the evaluation of case studies, data analysis/interpretation and experimental design.

Students will be prepared for the assessment through enquiry-based learning (EBL) exercises, activities delivered through platforms such as Polls Everywhere and discussion boards. In addition, on-line quizzes will be used to help students track their progress and workshops where students work through case study questions, data analysis and experimental design exercises will facilitate peer learning and provide formative feedback.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

 LO4 Analyse experimental data relating to the study of cell signalling.
 LO5 Critically evaluate the way modern therapeutics target defective signalling pathways to treat disease.

Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
Cell signalling underlies the ability of cells to sense their environment and respond. In multicellular organisms, individual cells receive and integrate vast amounts of information that they use to modify their behaviour to ensure development and survival of the organism as a whole. Disruption in these lines of communication underlies almost all disease.

Despite the apparent complexity, diverse signalling processes are carried out by very similar sets of molecular components that interact in common patterns. This module will be taught by focussing on the common molecular themes and concepts that underlie normal cell signalling. This will be interspersed with disease case studies that show how disruption of these processes affects cells, tissues, and the whole organism. The module will be taught via live on-campus sessions. There will be synchronous sessions that also cover questions and answers and discussion points raised in the week’s material – focussing on ‘how do we know this’ to introduce students to research methodologies and data interrogation. Interactive discussion will be encouraged through enquiry-based learning (EBL) exercises, activities delivered through platforms such as Polls Everywhere, discussion boards and live on-campus workshops.

Assessment will follow the two cycle assessment strategy, comprising an open-book on-line assessment and an in person, unseen exam, that will focus on the evaluation of case studies, data analysis/interpretation.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

• Provide knowledge and understanding of the molecular mechanisms that allow cells to communicate with each other;
• Explain the common molecular themes and concepts that underlie normal cell signalling, illustrating these with specific examples;
• Illustrate how defects in these signalling processes can result in a variety of diseases;
• Outline the techniques that are used to investigate and define these pathways and to describe how these techniques are used in drug discovery programmes of research;
Marketing Module Synopsis
Cell signalling underlies the ability of cells to sense their environment and respond. In multicellular organisms, individual cells receive and integrate vast amounts of information that they use to modify their behaviour to ensure the development and survival of the organism as a whole. Disruption in these lines of communication underlies almost all disease.

Despite the apparent complexity, diverse signalling processes are carried out by very similar sets of molecular components that interact in common patterns. This module will be taught via lectures which focus on the common molecular themes and concepts that underlie normal cell signalling. This will be interspersed with disease case studies that show how disruption of these processes affect cells, tissues, and the whole organism.

Assessment will include an open-book on-line assessment and an in person, unseen exam, which will focus on the evaluation of case studies, data analysis/interpretation.
Outline Syllabus
Part 1: Introduction to Cell Signalling will be a general overview of the key principles of cell signalling and highlight the world-leading research being carried out at Liverpool

Part 2: 'Getting the message – Information transfer across membranes' will look at the ways cells have evolved to sense environmental signals at their membrane. This will include a discussion of transmembrane receptors linked to enzymatic activity, transmembrane receptors linked to G proteins, the ion channel family, and membrane-permeant signals (nitric oxide, oxygen, steroid hormones). It will also include case studies to highlight how disruption in these processes underlies human disease.

Part 3: 'Information processing inside the cell' will show how cells deal with the environmental information once it gets inside the cell. This will include a discussion of the different molecular 'currencies' that cells use to transfer/process information and make decisions (protein-protein interactions, conformational change, post-translational modifications, subcellular localisation, small signalling mediators etc). It will also include disease case studies.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching on this module will be delivered by live on-campus sessions (30 hours of lectures and 2 hours of workshops). The synchronous sessions will also cover questions and answers and discussion points raised in the week’s material – focus will particularly be on ‘how do we know this’ to introduce students to research methodologies and data interrogation. Interactive discussion will be encouraged through enquiry-based learning (EBL) exercises, activities delivered through platforms such as Polls Everywhere and discussion boards.

Self-directed learning: Guided and self-directed reading, reflection on learning, formative assessment (quizzes, discussion questions for synchronous sessions) and preparation for summative assessments.

Inclusivity: Students will have access to materials online such as teaching materials and online discussion boards. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Research-connected teaching: Students will have the opportunity to discuss contemporary research to apply new perspectives to their learning.

Active and peer-learning: Students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant top issues and share with each other their values and perspectives on preparing for their assignments. Similarly, there is an expectation that students will prepare and actively research topics for dissemination and discussion with each other both in the classroom environment and on the virtual learning environment (CANVAS). Workshops will be incorporated into the module that will allow students to work through case studies and data analysis problems. The format of these workshops will facilitate group work, active and peer learning and will also provide students with formative feedback to reinforce their understanding.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions and learning tasks. Students will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of academic writing, persuasive debate and applying research and theory to practice.

Digital Fluency: All materials will be made available on CANVAS.

Global Citizenship: Students will share their own perspectives on practice issues and reflect on local, national and global strategies and policy. They will discuss and analyse these in relation to healthcare practice both domestically and internationally.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment for this module will involve both open-book (Cycle 1; worth 40% of the the overall module mark) and unseen exam assessments (Cycle 2; worth 60%) which focus on the evaluation of case studies, data analysis/interpretation and experimental design.

Students will be prepared for the assessment through enquiry-based learning (EBL) exercises, activities delivered through platforms such as Polls Everywhere and discussion boards. In addition, on-line quizzes will be used to help students track their progress and workshops where students work through case study questions, data analysis and experimental design exercises will facilitate peer learning and provide formative feedback.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
Cell signalling underlies the ability of cells to sense their environment and respond. In multicellular organisms, individual cells receive and integrate vast amounts of information that they use to modify their behaviour to ensure development and survival of the organism as a whole. Disruption in these lines of communication underlies almost all disease.

Despite the apparent complexity, diverse signalling processes are carried out by very similar sets of molecular components that interact in common patterns. This module will be taught by focussing on the common molecular themes and concepts that underlie normal cell signalling. This will be interspersed with disease case studies that show how disruption of these processes affects cells, tissues, and the whole organism. The module will be taught via live on-campus sessions. There will be synchronous sessions that also cover questions and answers and discussion points raised in the week’s material – focussing on ‘how do we know this’ to introduce students to research methodologies and data interrogation. Interactive discussion will be encouraged through enquiry-based learning (EBL) exercises, activities delivered through platforms such as Polls Everywhere, discussion boards and live on-campus workshops.

Assessment will follow the two cycle assessment strategy, comprising an open-book on-line assessment and an in person, unseen exam, that will focus on the evaluation of case studies, data analysis/interpretation.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

• Provide knowledge and understanding of the molecular mechanisms that allow cells to communicate with each other;
• Explain the common molecular themes and concepts that underlie normal cell signalling, illustrating these with specific examples;
• Illustrate how defects in these signalling processes can result in a variety of diseases;
• Outline the techniques that are used to investigate and define these pathways and to describe how these techniques are used in drug discovery programmes of research;
Marketing Module Synopsis
Cell signalling underlies the ability of cells to sense their environment and respond. In multicellular organisms, individual cells receive and integrate vast amounts of information that they use to modify their behaviour to ensure the development and survival of the organism as a whole. Disruption in these lines of communication underlies almost all disease.

Despite the apparent complexity, diverse signalling processes are carried out by very similar sets of molecular components that interact in common patterns. This module will be taught via lectures which focus on the common molecular themes and concepts that underlie normal cell signalling. This will be interspersed with disease case studies that show how disruption of these processes affect cells, tissues, and the whole organism.

Assessment will include an open-book on-line assessment and an in person, unseen exam, which will focus on the evaluation of case studies, data analysis/interpretation.
Outline Syllabus
Part 1: Introduction to Cell Signalling will be a general overview of the key principles of cell signalling and highlight the world-leading research being carried out at Liverpool

Part 2: 'Getting the message – Information transfer across membranes' will look at the ways cells have evolved to sense environmental signals at their membrane. This will include a discussion of transmembrane receptors linked to enzymatic activity, transmembrane receptors linked to G proteins, the ion channel family, and membrane-permeant signals (nitric oxide, oxygen, steroid hormones). It will also include case studies to highlight how disruption in these processes underlies human disease.

Part 3: 'Information processing inside the cell' will show how cells deal with the environmental information once it gets inside the cell. This will include a discussion of the different molecular 'currencies' that cells use to transfer/process information and make decisions (protein-protein interactions, conformational change, post-translational modifications, subcellular localisation, small signalling mediators etc). It will also include disease case studies.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching on this module will be delivered by live on-campus sessions (30 hours of lectures and 2 hours of workshops). The synchronous sessions will also cover questions and answers and discussion points raised in the week’s material – focus will particularly be on ‘how do we know this’ to introduce students to research methodologies and data interrogation. Interactive discussion will be encouraged through enquiry-based learning (EBL) exercises, activities delivered through platforms such as Polls Everywhere and discussion boards.

Self-directed learning: Guided and self-directed reading, reflection on learning, formative assessment (quizzes, discussion questions for synchronous sessions) and preparation for summative assessments.

Inclusivity: Students will have access to materials online such as teaching materials and online discussion boards. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Research-connected teaching: Students will have the opportunity to discuss contemporary research to apply new perspectives to their learning.

Active and peer-learning: Students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant top issues and share with each other their values and perspectives on preparing for their assignments. Similarly, there is an expectation that students will prepare and actively research topics for dissemination and discussion with each other both in the classroom environment and on the virtual learning environment (CANVAS). Workshops will be incorporated into the module that will allow students to work through case studies and data analysis problems. The format of these workshops will facilitate group work, active and peer learning and will also provide students with formative feedback to reinforce their understanding.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions and learning tasks. Students will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of academic writing, persuasive debate and applying research and theory to practice.

Digital Fluency: All materials will be made available on CANVAS.

Global Citizenship: Students will share their own perspectives on practice issues and reflect on local, national and global strategies and policy. They will discuss and analyse these in relation to healthcare practice both domestically and internationally.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment for this module will involve both open-book (Cycle 1; worth 40% of the the overall module mark) and unseen exam assessments (Cycle 2; worth 60%) which focus on the evaluation of case studies, data analysis/interpretation and experimental design.

Students will be prepared for the assessment through enquiry-based learning (EBL) exercises, activities delivered through platforms such as Polls Everywhere and discussion boards. In addition, on-line quizzes will be used to help students track their progress and workshops where students work through case study questions, data analysis and experimental design exercises will facilitate peer learning and provide formative feedback.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Analyse and evaluate the fundamental features of a range of important cell signalling mechanisms.
 LO2 Evaluate the nature and role of the different molecular components of intracellular signalling pathways.
 LO3 Explain how cell signalling processes may be defective, or modified, in a variety of different diseases.
 LO4 Analyse experimental data relating to the study of cell signalling.
 LO5 Critically evaluate the way modern therapeutics target defective signalling pathways to treat disease.

Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
Cell signalling underlies the ability of cells to sense their environment and respond. In multicellular organisms, individual cells receive and integrate vast amounts of information that they use to modify their behaviour to ensure development and survival of the organism as a whole. Disruption in these lines of communication underlies almost all disease.

Despite the apparent complexity, diverse signalling processes are carried out by very similar sets of molecular components that interact in common patterns. This module will be taught by focussing on the common molecular themes and concepts that underlie normal cell signalling. This will be interspersed with disease case studies that show how disruption of these processes affects cells, tissues, and the whole organism. The module will be taught via live on-campus sessions. There will be synchronous sessions that also cover questions and answers and discussion points raised in the week’s material – focussing on ‘how do we know this’ to introduce students to research methodologies and data interrogation. Interactive discussion will be encouraged through enquiry-based learning (EBL) exercises, activities delivered through platforms such as Polls Everywhere, discussion boards and live on-campus workshops.

Assessment will follow the two cycle assessment strategy, comprising an open-book on-line assessment and an in person, unseen exam, that will focus on the evaluation of case studies, data analysis/interpretation.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

• Provide knowledge and understanding of the molecular mechanisms that allow cells to communicate with each other;
• Explain the common molecular themes and concepts that underlie normal cell signalling, illustrating these with specific examples;
• Illustrate how defects in these signalling processes can result in a variety of diseases;
• Outline the techniques that are used to investigate and define these pathways and to describe how these techniques are used in drug discovery programmes of research;
Marketing Module Synopsis
Cell signalling underlies the ability of cells to sense their environment and respond. In multicellular organisms, individual cells receive and integrate vast amounts of information that they use to modify their behaviour to ensure the development and survival of the organism as a whole. Disruption in these lines of communication underlies almost all disease.

Despite the apparent complexity, diverse signalling processes are carried out by very similar sets of molecular components that interact in common patterns. This module will be taught via lectures which focus on the common molecular themes and concepts that underlie normal cell signalling. This will be interspersed with disease case studies that show how disruption of these processes affect cells, tissues, and the whole organism.

Assessment will include an open-book on-line assessment and an in person, unseen exam, which will focus on the evaluation of case studies, data analysis/interpretation.
Outline Syllabus
Part 1: Introduction to Cell Signalling will be a general overview of the key principles of cell signalling and highlight the world-leading research being carried out at Liverpool

Part 2: 'Getting the message – Information transfer across membranes' will look at the ways cells have evolved to sense environmental signals at their membrane. This will include a discussion of transmembrane receptors linked to enzymatic activity, transmembrane receptors linked to G proteins, the ion channel family, and membrane-permeant signals (nitric oxide, oxygen, steroid hormones). It will also include case studies to highlight how disruption in these processes underlies human disease.

Part 3: 'Information processing inside the cell' will show how cells deal with the environmental information once it gets inside the cell. This will include a discussion of the different molecular 'currencies' that cells use to transfer/process information and make decisions (protein-protein interactions, conformational change, post-translational modifications, subcellular localisation, small signalling mediators etc). It will also include disease case studies.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching on this module will be delivered by live on-campus sessions (30 hours of lectures and 2 hours of workshops). The synchronous sessions will also cover questions and answers and discussion points raised in the week’s material – focus will particularly be on ‘how do we know this’ to introduce students to research methodologies and data interrogation. Interactive discussion will be encouraged through enquiry-based learning (EBL) exercises, activities delivered through platforms such as Polls Everywhere and discussion boards.

Self-directed learning: Guided and self-directed reading, reflection on learning, formative assessment (quizzes, discussion questions for synchronous sessions) and preparation for summative assessments.

Inclusivity: Students will have access to materials online such as teaching materials and online discussion boards. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Research-connected teaching: Students will have the opportunity to discuss contemporary research to apply new perspectives to their learning.

Active and peer-learning: Students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant top issues and share with each other their values and perspectives on preparing for their assignments. Similarly, there is an expectation that students will prepare and actively research topics for dissemination and discussion with each other both in the classroom environment and on the virtual learning environment (CANVAS). Workshops will be incorporated into the module that will allow students to work through case studies and data analysis problems. The format of these workshops will facilitate group work, active and peer learning and will also provide students with formative feedback to reinforce their understanding.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions and learning tasks. Students will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of academic writing, persuasive debate and applying research and theory to practice.

Digital Fluency: All materials will be made available on CANVAS.

Global Citizenship: Students will share their own perspectives on practice issues and reflect on local, national and global strategies and policy. They will discuss and analyse these in relation to healthcare practice both domestically and internationally.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment for this module will involve both open-book (Cycle 1; worth 40% of the the overall module mark) and unseen exam assessments (Cycle 2; worth 60%) which focus on the evaluation of case studies, data analysis/interpretation and experimental design.

Students will be prepared for the assessment through enquiry-based learning (EBL) exercises, activities delivered through platforms such as Polls Everywhere and discussion boards. In addition, on-line quizzes will be used to help students track their progress and workshops where students work through case study questions, data analysis and experimental design exercises will facilitate peer learning and provide formative feedback.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Analyse and evaluate the fundamental features of a range of important cell signalling mechanisms.
 LO2 Evaluate the nature and role of the different molecular components of intracellular signalling pathways.
 LO3 Explain how cell signalling processes may be defective, or modified, in a variety of different diseases.
 LO4 Analyse experimental data relating to the study of cell signalling.
 LO5 Critically evaluate the way modern therapeutics target defective signalling pathways to treat disease.
